20. 다음 글에서 필자가 주장하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

It is not the case that one can follow the law and assume that one is acting ethically. Throughout history, many laws have turned out to be an ethical disgrace when viewed with hindsight. Slavery is just one example of a situation that was legal, but that subsequently was declared immoral. Child labour is another. There are also laws and regulations that one has to break in certain situations if one is to act ethically. Jumping a red light or crossing a solid double line on the road may be the correct decision if it means getting a critically ill child to hospital sooner, and thereby increasing the chances of saving the child's life. Law and ethics are related, but they are not necessarily correlated or causally related. We must be cautious both when technology is changing and about allowing the law to take precedence over ethics. Particularly in the case of new technology, for example, technological singularity, a legal basis does not yet exist. In such cases, one must resort to the legal philosophy of the exception and the limitations of the law on the one hand, and ethical reflections on the other hand.
* disgrace: 수치  ** hindsight: 뒤늦은 깨달음  *** singularity: 특이점
errors.correct: ⑤ 법이 항상 윤리를 보장하지 않기에 윤리적 판단이 우선되어야 한다.
errors.wrong: ③ 첨단 기술의 발전 속도에 맞춰 법적 기반을 서둘러 마련해야 한다.

errors.question:
22. 다음 글의 요지로 가장 적절한 것은?

The individual preoccupation with status or relative social position is not, from the perspective of evolutionary psychology, a character defect. It is, rather, an evolved adaptive mechanism to the ancestral reality that 'falling behind one's local rivals can be lethal'. When food supplies are intermittent because of wars or acts of nature, class affiliation is frequently the difference between survival and starvation. The law of natural selection is to blame for why people do not suffer the loss of status well, and will sometimes (if not frequently) resort to extreme measures to avoid it. The key point is that effective behavioral expressions of instinctive drives are culture- or context-specific. The immediate source of status could be hunting skill, age, number of wives or children, college admission scores, the make of a pickup truck, or the label on a woman's handbag. The purchase, use, and display of goods is the predominant means by which people seek to communicate their position to others in mature capitalist systems. Consumption behavior is also a primary object of imitation.
* lethal: 치명적인  ** intermittent: 간헐적인  *** affiliation: 소속
errors.correct: ⑤ 인간의 진화적 특성인 지위 유지 본능은 문화나 상황에 따라 다르게 표현된다.
errors.wrong: ② 인간은 식량 공급의 불규칙성에 대비하여 공동체를 형성하고 유지했다.

errors.question:
23. 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

One behavioral measurement of customer loyalty is the length of time a customer has been buying a brand. A shopper who has been purchasing a brand regularly for ten years would be considered more loyal than one who has been doing so for four years. However, relying on behavioral data alone is inadequate because it might only measure spurious loyalty, behavior that resembles brand loyalty but is not genuine loyalty caused by both true brand preference and regular buying. Rather, it is merely repeat purchase behavior (behavioral brand loyalty), buying a brand repeatedly due to factors such as indifference, convenience, low price, or unavailability of the preferred brand (versus brand preference). Consequently, in addition to behavioral data, marketers should also collect attitudinal or preference data such as measures of customer satisfaction, intent to repurchase, and brand advocacy, a measure of attitudinal loyalty that entails planning to recommend or recommending the brand to others. Brand advocacy can be measured simply by asking customers how likely they are to recommend a specific brand to a friend. Such customers can be leveraged to drive word-of-mouth campaigns.
* spurious: 겉보기만 그럴듯한  ** leverage: 활용하다
errors.correct: ① considerations for measuring true customer brand loyalty
errors.wrong: ③ behavioral characteristics of customers with strong brand loyalty

errors.question:
25. 다음 도표의 내용과 일치하지 않는 것은?

Trends in Smartphone Ownership Among U.S. Children (2015 vs. 2021)

The graph above shows the percentage of American children aged 8 to 18 who owned a smartphone in 2015 and 2021. In 2015, fewer than 20% of children aged 8 to 10 owned a smartphone, and the ownership rate gradually increased with age, continuing to rise steadily through age 18. In 2021, 31% of 8-year-olds and 32% of 9-year-olds had smartphones — more than double the rates recorded for the same age groups in 2015. In 2021, the sharpest increase in ownership occurred between ages 11 and 12, whereas in 2015, the largest jump was between ages 10 and 11. In each age group of 14- to 18-year-olds in 2021, over 90% owned smartphones, with 17-year-olds showing the highest rate, at 97%. Additionally, in 2021, more than two thirds of 12- and 13-year-olds had smartphones, and from age 14 onward, ownership rates fluctuated rather than continued to rise steadily with age.
* fluctuate: 오르내리다
errors.correct: ④ 2021년에 14~18세의 각 연령대에서 90% 이상이 스마트폰을 소유했으며, 17세가 97%로 가장 높은 비율을 보였다.
errors.wrong: ② 2021년에 8세와 9세 어린이의 스마트폰 소유율은 2015년 같은 연령대의 두 배 이상이었다.

errors.question:
31. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

One of the central tenets of modern psychology is that perceptual and cognitive processes arise in the brain. Even if these processes are about objects in the world and perceived through sensory organs, the brain's role is still considered central. Implicit in this view is that all human brains are organized in similar ways. This turns out to be supported over and over again. For example, regardless of gender, age, ethnic background, racial identification, native language, and any other feature that distinguishes one human from another, brain regions serve the same functions across these distinctions. For example, the occipital lobe processes visual information for all sighted persons (indeed, all sighted mammals). Wernicke's area and Broca's area are language areas in all human brains. The primary auditory cortex processes input from the cochlea in all human brains. Neurosurgeons may need to be aware of slight deviations in individual human brains — one region may be shifted a few millimeters forward or backward relative to other individuals — but by and large, this rule of brain _____________ has been upheld in modern science.
* tenet: 신조, 주의  ** occipital lobe: 후두엽  *** cochlea: (귓속) 달팽이관

32. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

The level of sharing is not always equal when cultures interact, but there is typically some degree of sharing. For example, when one group is captured and transported to another culture, the captured individuals have no say in how they will be treated or what behaviors they will be forced to practice. Often, as a matter of survival, they must learn some of the captors' language and behaviors; their original cultural dress may be removed and they may be given dress from the culture that captured them. This was often the practice with the capture of individuals to serve as slaves within the US culture. However, US slave records have suggested that, even with the provision of elements of dress from the enslaving culture, the enslaved found ways to modify dress to present and preserve their own cultural aesthetics, as in tying a headscarf to approximate a "wrapper" from their West African roots. What was a sign of oppression from plantation owners' perspectives may have _______________________ among female slaves, carrying forward into modern culture as various ornate wrapped headdresses.
* ornate: 화려하게 장식된
errors.correct: ② actually been a symbol of identity
errors.wrong: ⑤ been used to express a desire to enter the ruling culture

errors.question:
34. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

In his study of cooperative foraging among the Inujjuamiut, Eric Alden Smith found that the composition of foraging groups often conformed to predictions. For hunt types in which the highest per capita returns were achieved via solitary hunting, such as ptarmigan hunting, cooperative groups were rare. For other hunt types, however, there was frequently a mismatch between the observed group sizes and the seemingly optimal group size. When hunting beluga whales, for instance, per capita returns declined when group sizes exceeded 6 hunters, but the average group size was 10.7 individuals. In an analogous study of foraging in the Indonesian community of Lamalera, Michael Alvard and David A. Nolin determined that cooperative whaling provides higher per capita returns than other foraging activities. When whaling crews do not detect whales and resort to pursuits of other species, the per capita returns decline substantially as a function of crew size. Together, these two studies support the prediction that _______________________.
* foraging: 수렵 채집  ** solitary: 단독의  *** ptarmigan: 들꿩
errors.correct: ② observed group sizes will often exceed the optimum
errors.wrong: ③ solitary hunting will underperform cooperative hunting

errors.question:
36. 주어진 글 다음에 이어질 글의 순서로 가장 적절한 것은?

Some concede that what gives meaning to life can occasionally change, yet believe that at each point in time there must be only one thing that gives life meaning.

(A) Nor do we think that there is anything inappropriate in performing various types of volunteer work (addressing various moral concerns, or benefiting different people), or in finding pleasure and happiness in different activities or hobbies.

(B) Thus, I may have a meaningful life thanks to my family life, my career, my hobby, my philanthropic activity, and my spiritual work at the same period of time. Of course, we would not want to spread ourselves too thin over too many aspects of life, but that is not the same thing as saying that we should focus only on one.

(C) But we do not regularly think that it is problematic to value various issues at the same time. For example, we do not think that there is anything wrong in taking aesthetic pleasure in many different paintings, in a variety of artistic styles, or in several different artistic fields (for example, both visual art and music).
* concede: 인정하다  ** philanthropic: 자선의  *** aesthetic: 미적인

38. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은? [3점]

When we first come to attempt some task, we have accumulated almost none of the habit.

Learning is usually thought of as the relatively permanent acquired capability for performing some action. As such, experimenters often think of learning as a kind of "accumulated quantity." ( ① ) Many years ago, the state underlying performance was termed "habit," where we would say that practice "strengthens habit," and "stronger habit" allows more effective performance to occur. ( ② ) Of course, this says nothing about what habit is, but it does underscore the idea that we are attempting to study those principles that govern the accumulation of habit with practice. ( ③ ) Then, with additional practice, habit is thought to build in strength, and it is this stronger (in some sense) habit that allows improved performance to occur. ( ④ ) A key point is that our focus is not on the change in performance, but rather on the change in the state of habit that underlies performance. ( ⑤ ) This distinction is a critical one, and it is the basis for much of the methodology in the laboratory study of learning.
* underscore: 강조하다

39. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은?

Furthermore, your body will react by trying to remove further sensory insults.

The instinctive aversion we feel to harmful smells is combined with other physiological responses. For example, the trigeminal nerve can be triggered by irritant particles. ( ① ) This nerve stretches across your face and can send strong signals of pain when triggered. ( ② ) So not only will your brain tell you that you are at risk of being injured by whatever is giving off that horrible smell, it may also try to warn you from approaching it by making you experience physical pain. ( ③ ) Like the pain telling you to remove your hand from a burning metal surface, this pain aims to force you to move somewhere safer. ( ④ ) For instance, being exposed to a pungent smell might cause your eyes to tear and your nose to run, which may make it harder for you to breathe. ( ⑤ ) The increase in fluid production in your eyes and nose is to dilute whatever toxic molecules you were unlucky enough to breathe in, while the shortness of breath may be caused by your windpipes contracting in order to stop you from breathing in further particles.
* aversion: 혐오감  ** trigeminal nerve: 삼차 신경  *** pungent: 강하게 자극하는

40. 다음 글의 내용을 한 문장으로 요약하고자 한다. 빈칸 (A), (B)에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

In many contexts, people are motivated to make accurate judgments of others, unbiased by stereotypes and other factors. This motivation may arise from a temporary goal (e.g., to hire the best person for a position) or to consistently avoid prejudiced responses (e.g., to be an egalitarian person). These differing motivations to be accurate both contribute to reducing the application of activated stereotypes. In a study showing the former, participants who were told that they would have to share and explain their judgments of members of occupational groups showed lower use of stereotypes compared with participants whose judgments remained anonymous. Interestingly, participants who had to explain their ratings but in whom a cognitive load had been imposed showed higher levels of stereotyping. This result indicates that avoiding the use of stereotypes in judgment can be effortful, requiring cognitive resources. An example of the latter motivation is a study on the suppression of stereotypes. When people are instructed to avoid using stereotypes to judge others, they can succeed in doing so. When they are under a cognitive load or no longer feel that they need to inhibit their stereotypes, however, judgments are colored by stereotypical associations.
* egalitarian: 평등주의의  ** anonymous: 익명인

People who are motivated to judge others ___(A)___ can reduce reliance on stereotypes, but they are more likely to fall back on habitual biases when ___(B)___ cognitive strain.

17. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?
From infancy, humans develop the ability to differentiate living things from inanimate objects based on movement patterns and sounds — animals move and sound differently than machines. Yet the neural systems responsible for these distinctions are imperfect, making it challenging to separate natural phenomena from what might seem supernatural. Our minds constantly scan for intentional actors, leading us to err when we hear mysterious sounds in darkness. What causes metal particles to move toward magnets? Why do swollen rivers appear furious? Dreams and visions reinforce our tendency to imagine various purposeful entities exist. Language reinforces this, as grammar requires actors for actions — we say wind \"blows\" and sun \"shines.\" _______________ because such mistakes typically carry fewer consequences than the reverse error. Confusing a piece of wood for a predator may be embarrassing, but confusing a predator for wood could be deadly.
errors.correct: ③ Our minds have a bias toward overdetection of agency
errors.wrong: ② We humans put process over purpose in our actions

errors.question:
[A], [B], [C]의 각 네모 안에서 어법에 맞는 표현으로 가장 적절한 것은? (12점)

A psychologist at Yale University proposed a "fat tax." This tax would be for high-fat products, mainly junk food, like potato chips and hot dogs. It would be a "luxury tax," like the tax on tobacco and alcohol, [A] [that / which] are also products people use for personal pleasure even though they have high health risks. [B] [Even if / Even though] this tax has some supporters, it's not likely to pass because the average person doesn't want to be told how to eat by what some call the "fat police." Even if such a tax were to pass, I doubt it would help to reduce the number of overweight people. Obesity may be a social problem, but losing weight and practicing healthy eating habits is definitely a personal struggle [C] [that / what], of course, is not limited to only one.
errors.correct: ⑤ A: which, B: Even if, C: that
errors.wrong: ④ A: that, B: Even though, C: what

[A], [B], [C]의 각 네모 안에서 어법에 맞는 표현으로 가장 적절한 것은? (12점)

One domain in which this is of considerable significance is music's potentially damaging effects on the ability to drive safely. Evidence suggests an association between loud, fast music and reckless driving, but how might music's ability to influence driving in this way be explained? One possibility is [B] [that / what] drivers adjust to temporal regularities in music, and that their speed is influenced accordingly. In other words, just as faster music causes people to eat faster, [C] [so / such] it causes people to drive at faster speeds.
errors.correct: ② A: where, B: that, C: so
errors.wrong: ① A: which, B: that, C: so

①D̲e̲s̲p̲i̲t̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲p̲l̲a̲n̲ ̲b̲e̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲d̲e̲s̲i̲g̲n̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲i̲n̲s̲p̲i̲r̲e̲ ̲e̲c̲o̲n̲o̲m̲i̲c̲ ̲g̲r̲o̲w̲t̲h̲, conservationists criticized it harshly. ②B̲e̲c̲a̲u̲s̲e̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲l̲a̲c̲k̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲p̲r̲o̲p̲e̲r̲ ̲r̲e̲g̲u̲l̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲s̲, many historic buildings were demolished without any public consultation. The Prime Minister, ③k̲n̲o̲w̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲t̲ ̲o̲p̲p̲o̲s̲i̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲w̲o̲u̲l̲d̲ ̲b̲e̲ ̲s̲t̲r̲o̲n̲g̲, nevertheless pushed forward with the controversial proposal. ④A̲l̲t̲h̲o̲u̲g̲h̲ ̲r̲e̲n̲o̲v̲a̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲l̲d̲ ̲s̲t̲r̲u̲c̲t̲u̲r̲e̲s̲ ̲i̲s̲ ̲e̲x̲p̲e̲n̲s̲i̲v̲e̲, the cultural value makes it worthwhile in the long run. Many homeowners, ⑤f̲r̲u̲s̲t̲r̲a̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲b̲y̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲e̲n̲d̲l̲e̲s̲s̲ ̲b̲u̲r̲e̲a̲u̲c̲r̲a̲t̲i̲c̲ ̲d̲e̲l̲a̲y̲s̲, welcomed the new policy with open arms.

다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?

It seemed that all of the previous magnificence of the Byzantine Empire ①h̲a̲d̲ ̲c̲o̲m̲p̲l̲e̲t̲e̲l̲y̲ ̲d̲i̲s̲a̲p̲p̲e̲a̲r̲e̲d̲ until Emperor Justinian finally took the throne. Justinian helped his suffering people by recovering the lands, many of ②w̲h̲i̲c̲h̲ ̲h̲a̲d̲ ̲f̲a̲l̲l̲e̲n̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲o̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲h̲a̲n̲d̲s̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲n̲o̲r̲t̲h̲e̲r̲n̲ ̲i̲n̲v̲a̲d̲e̲r̲s̲. With the invaluable help of General Belisarius, the areas in Northern Africa were quickly taken back in 533. In 536, Justinian sent Belisarius to fight in Italy. Perception is not a passive process. The available amount of stimuli can be summarized and reduced through organization. This process is known as the "formation of super-signs." The first step entails the automatic "summarization" of similar signs or organizational structures into a super-sign, in which the ①essential elements are emphasized. This means that at first glance the observer does not perceive all details. He sees, for example, only the form of a wall with the most important openings but without any details. This ②increases the quantity of information available for reception. The work of information storage is diminished and we can thus ③better perceive and monitor our environment. 23. 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

One behavioral measurement of customer loyalty is the length of time a customer has been buying a brand. A shopper who has been purchasing a brand regularly for ten years would be considered more loyal than one who has been doing so for four years. However, relying on behavioral data alone is inadequate because it might only measure spurious loyalty, behavior that resembles brand loyalty but is not genuine loyalty caused by both true brand preference and regular buying. Rather, it is merely repeat purchase behavior (behavioral brand loyalty), buying a brand repeatedly due to factors such as indifference, convenience, low price, or unavailability of the preferred brand (versus brand preference). Consequently, in addition to behavioral data, marketers should also collect attitudinal or preference data such as measures of customer satisfaction, intent to repurchase, and brand advocacy, a measure of attitudinal loyalty that entails planning to recommend or recommending the brand to others. Brand advocacy can be measured simply by asking customers how likely they are to recommend a specific brand to a friend. Such customers can be leveraged to drive word-of-mouth campaigns.
* spurious: 겉보기만 그럴듯한  ** leverage: 활용하다
errors.correct: ① considerations for measuring true customer brand loyalty
errors.wrong: ③ behavioral characteristics of customers with strong brand loyalty

24. 다음 글의 제목으로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

Much of what we see and feel is selected by complex filtration systems, resulting in our perception of the wondrous world around us, at the cost of several illusions and limitations. Some of these costs are gladly paid for, whereas others are not. We begin with the very experience of time and space. The first illusion is our temporal orientation to the present. Although it may feel as if we are living in the now, the fact is that our perception lags behind real time by approximately 350 milliseconds, during which time information from the outside world is sensed, perceived, and interpreted by neural structures before being registered in conscious awareness. If we include our subsequent behavior, the estimation rises to 550 milliseconds−1 second. This means our conscious selves are actually perpetually living in the past. To compound this illusion, space is expanding and the Earth is moving rapidly, yet we do not feel as if the space we inhabit has changed, nor do we feel as if we are moving. We become accustomed to the constants in our lives, and it becomes easy to simply trust how we feel.
* perpetually: 영구히, 영속적으로
errors.correct: ⑤ The Illusion of Now: How Perception Distorts Time and Space
errors.wrong: ④ Measuring the Invisible: The Physics of Time and Space

31. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

One of the central tenets of modern psychology is that perceptual and cognitive processes arise in the brain. Even if these processes are about objects in the world and perceived through sensory organs, the brain's role is still considered central. Implicit in this view is that all human brains are organized in similar ways. This turns out to be supported over and over again. For example, regardless of gender, age, ethnic background, racial identification, native language, and any other feature that distinguishes one human from another, brain regions serve the same functions across these distinctions. For example, the occipital lobe processes visual information for all sighted persons (indeed, all sighted mammals). Wernicke's area and Broca's area are language areas in all human brains. The primary auditory cortex processes input from the cochlea in all human brains. Neurosurgeons may need to be aware of slight deviations in individual human brains — one region may be shifted a few millimeters forward or backward relative to other individuals — but by and large, this rule of brain _____________ has been upheld in modern science.
* tenet: 신조, 주의  ** occipital lobe: 후두엽  *** cochlea: (귓속) 달팽이관

32. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

The level of sharing is not always equal when cultures interact, but there is typically some degree of sharing. For example, when one group is captured and transported to another culture, the captured individuals have no say in how they will be treated or what behaviors they will be forced to practice. Often, as a matter of survival, they must learn some of the captors' language and behaviors; their original cultural dress may be removed and they may be given dress from the culture that captured them. This was often the practice with the capture of individuals to serve as slaves within the US culture. However, US slave records have suggested that, even with the provision of elements of dress from the enslaving culture, the enslaved found ways to modify dress to present and preserve their own cultural aesthetics, as in tying a headscarf to approximate a "wrapper" from their West African roots. What was a sign of oppression from plantation owners' perspectives may have _______________________ among female slaves, carrying forward into modern culture as various ornate wrapped headdresses.
* ornate: 화려하게 장식된
errors.correct: ② actually been a symbol of identity
errors.wrong: ③ represented the level of dressmaking ability

33. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

One advantage of thinking verbally is that language _______________________. By virtue of language and meaning, you can think about possible future events, about people who are far away, about promises made in the distant past. A rat or insect essentially lives in the immediate present and can respond only on the basis of what it can see, hear, and taste. Language allows people to see the present through the lens of those other, invisible facts and even to imagine possible events that have never occurred. This facility is powerfully helpful and liberating. As just one example, animals that have no language cannot possibly understand that some of this year's harvest has to be saved for planting next year, and they might eat their seed corn when they get hungry. They would feel better in the short run, but next year they would have nothing to plant and hence no crop at all. It is hardly an accident that our species is the only one to engage in farming, even though a great many species eat plants.
errors.correct: ① liberates you from the here and now
errors.wrong: ④ allows animals and humans to detect distant threats

34. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

In his study of cooperative foraging among the Inujjuamiut, Eric Alden Smith found that the composition of foraging groups often conformed to predictions. For hunt types in which the highest per capita returns were achieved via solitary hunting, such as ptarmigan hunting, cooperative groups were rare. For other hunt types, however, there was frequently a mismatch between the observed group sizes and the seemingly optimal group size. When hunting beluga whales, for instance, per capita returns declined when group sizes exceeded 6 hunters, but the average group size was 10.7 individuals. In an analogous study of foraging in the Indonesian community of Lamalera, Michael Alvard and David A. Nolin determined that cooperative whaling provides higher per capita returns than other foraging activities. When whaling crews do not detect whales and resort to pursuits of other species, the per capita returns decline substantially as a function of crew size. Together, these two studies support the prediction that _______________________.
* foraging: 수렵 채집  ** solitary: 단독의  *** ptarmigan: 들꿩
errors.correct: ② observed group sizes will often exceed the optimum
errors.wrong: ① lower per capita returns will reduce group size

Some concede that what gives meaning to life can occasionally change, yet believe that at each point in time there must be only one thing that gives life meaning.

(A) Nor do we think that there is anything inappropriate in performing various types of volunteer work (addressing various moral concerns, or benefiting different people), or in finding pleasure and happiness in different activities or hobbies.

(B) Thus, I may have a meaningful life thanks to my family life, my career, my hobby, my philanthropic activity, and my spiritual work at the same period of time. Of course, we would not want to spread ourselves too thin over too many aspects of life, but that is not the same thing as saying that we should focus only on one.

(C) But we do not regularly think that it is problematic to value various issues at the same time. For example, we do not think that there is anything wrong in taking aesthetic pleasure in many different paintings, in a variety of artistic styles, or in several different artistic fields (for example, both visual art and music).
* concede: 인정하다  ** philanthropic: 자선의  *** aesthetic: 미적인

39. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은?

Furthermore, your body will react by trying to remove further sensory insults.

The instinctive aversion we feel to harmful smells is combined with other physiological responses. For example, the trigeminal nerve can be triggered by irritant particles. ( ① ) This nerve stretches across your face and can send strong signals of pain when triggered. ( ② ) So not only will your brain tell you that you are at risk of being injured by whatever is giving off that horrible smell, it may also try to warn you from approaching it by making you experience physical pain. ( ③ ) Like the pain telling you to remove your hand from a burning metal surface, this pain aims to force you to move somewhere safer. ( ④ ) For instance, being exposed to a pungent smell might cause your eyes to tear and your nose to run, which may make it harder for you to breathe. ( ⑤ ) The increase in fluid production in your eyes and nose is to dilute whatever toxic molecules you were unlucky enough to breathe in, while the shortness of breath may be caused by your windpipes contracting in order to stop you from breathing in further particles.
* aversion: 혐오감  ** trigeminal nerve: 삼차 신경  *** pungent: 강하게 자극하는

40. 다음 글의 내용을 한 문장으로 요약하고자 한다. 빈칸 (A), (B)에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

In many contexts, people are motivated to make accurate judgments of others, unbiased by stereotypes and other factors. This motivation may arise from a temporary goal (e.g., to hire the best person for a position) or to consistently avoid prejudiced responses (e.g., to be an egalitarian person). These differing motivations to be accurate both contribute to reducing the application of activated stereotypes. In a study showing the former, participants who were told that they would have to share and explain their judgments of members of occupational groups showed lower use of stereotypes compared with participants whose judgments remained anonymous. Interestingly, participants who had to explain their ratings but in whom a cognitive load had been imposed showed higher levels of stereotyping. This result indicates that avoiding the use of stereotypes in judgment can be effortful, requiring cognitive resources. An example of the latter motivation is a study on the suppression of stereotypes. When people are instructed to avoid using stereotypes to judge others, they can succeed in doing so. When they are under a cognitive load or no longer feel that they need to inhibit their stereotypes, however, judgments are colored by stereotypical associations.
* egalitarian: 평등주의의  ** anonymous: 익명인

People who are motivated to judge others ___(A)___ can reduce reliance on stereotypes, but they are more likely to fall back on habitual biases when ___(B)___ cognitive strain.

In music direction, perfection of musical execution is the norm. It is also the expectation, conscious or not, of colleagues and audiences alike. Imperfection results in (a) visibility; people generally do not notice the workings of the music until they go wrong. Writers and directors (b) support absolute musical proficiency because fluency ensures maximum believability and comprehension. The better a language is spoken, the more communicative and emotional power it has. If stage music is supposed to appear from nowhere, it certainly should not trip and fall on its way in. For example, any audible flub by the accompanist at a vocal recital (who is by my definition the music director of the recital) is sure to turn the listener's attention to the piano when it should be on the (c) singer, and the pianist's error might well throw the singer off. Take another example: if an excessively loud music cue is suddenly heard in the midst of a quiet, tender dramatic moment of a play (or film), the intent of the drama will be (d) preserved. When music does encroach on a dramatic or entertainment setting on a stage, it should sound as if it belonged there, it should sound musically right, and it should leave a good impression. It is the music director's obligation to properly assimilate the music, to oversee its quality control, and to (e) connect the material with its listeners.
* flub: 실수  ** encroach: 끼어들다

(C)

In his study of cooperative foraging among the Inujjuamiut, Eric Alden Smith found that the composition of foraging groups often conformed to predictions. For hunt types in which the highest per capita returns were achieved via solitary hunting, such as ptarmigan hunting, cooperative groups were rare. For other hunt types, however, there was frequently a mismatch between the observed group sizes and the seemingly optimal group size. When hunting beluga whales, for instance, per capita returns declined when group sizes exceeded 6 hunters, but the average group size was 10.7 individuals. In an analogous study of foraging in the Indonesian community of Lamalera, Michael Alvard and David A. Nolin determined that cooperative whaling provides higher per capita returns than other foraging activities. When whaling crews do not detect whales and resort to pursuits of other species, the per capita returns decline substantially as a function of crew size. Together, these two studies support the prediction that _______________________.
* foraging: 수렵 채집  ** solitary: 단독의  *** ptarmigan: 들꿩
errors.correct: ② observed group sizes will often exceed the optimum
errors.wrong: ① lower per capita returns will reduce group size

21. 밑줄 친 pleasing to the eye가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

Valentin Haüy not only established the first school for the blind, but also introduced the first reliable and practical system for tactile printing. However, Haüy, and most educators of the blind for many subsequent decades, believed that in the education of the blind, everything should be done to establish a bond of vital unity between the blind and the sighted. This included the writing system, which had to be legible by both the sighted and the blind, and thus systems for the blind to read and write had to follow the principles derived from visual alphabets. As was carefully studied and demonstrated by Susana Millar's work on tactile reading, such systems remained difficult for the blind to learn despite the many improvements and modified systems. Millar's careful study of the functions and limitations of the sense of touch shows that the writing systems for the blind grounded on Roman symbols may have been 'pleasing to the eye', but lacked tangibility.

Perception is not a passive process. The available amount of stimuli can be summarized and reduced through organization. This process is known as the "formation of super-signs." The first step entails the automatic "summarization" of similar signs or organizational structures into a super-sign, in which the ①essential elements are emphasized. This means that at first glance the observer does not perceive all details. He sees, for example, only the form of a wall with the most important openings but without any details. This ②increases the quantity of information available for reception. The work of information storage is diminished and we can thus ③better perceive and monitor our environment. 23. 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

One behavioral measurement of customer loyalty is the length of time a customer has been buying a brand. A shopper who has been purchasing a brand regularly for ten years would be considered more loyal than one who has been doing so for four years. However, relying on behavioral data alone is inadequate because it might only measure spurious loyalty, behavior that resembles brand loyalty but is not genuine loyalty caused by both true brand preference and regular buying. Rather, it is merely repeat purchase behavior (behavioral brand loyalty), buying a brand repeatedly due to factors such as indifference, convenience, low price, or unavailability of the preferred brand (versus brand preference). Consequently, in addition to behavioral data, marketers should also collect attitudinal or preference data such as measures of customer satisfaction, intent to repurchase, and brand advocacy, a measure of attitudinal loyalty that entails planning to recommend or recommending the brand to others. Brand advocacy can be measured simply by asking customers how likely they are to recommend a specific brand to a friend. Such customers can be leveraged to drive word-of-mouth campaigns.
* spurious: 겉보기만 그럴듯한  ** leverage: 활용하다
errors.correct: ① considerations for measuring true customer brand loyalty
errors.wrong: ③ behavioral characteristics of customers with strong brand loyalty

31. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

One of the central tenets of modern psychology is that perceptual and cognitive processes arise in the brain. Even if these processes are about objects in the world and perceived through sensory organs, the brain's role is still considered central. Implicit in this view is that all human brains are organized in similar ways. This turns out to be supported over and over again. For example, regardless of gender, age, ethnic background, racial identification, native language, and any other feature that distinguishes one human from another, brain regions serve the same functions across these distinctions. For example, the occipital lobe processes visual information for all sighted persons (indeed, all sighted mammals). Wernicke's area and Broca's area are language areas in all human brains. The primary auditory cortex processes input from the cochlea in all human brains. Neurosurgeons may need to be aware of slight deviations in individual human brains — one region may be shifted a few millimeters forward or backward relative to other individuals — but by and large, this rule of brain _____________ has been upheld in modern science.
* tenet: 신조, 주의  ** occipital lobe: 후두엽  *** cochlea: (귓속) 달팽이관

32. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

The level of sharing is not always equal when cultures interact, but there is typically some degree of sharing. For example, when one group is captured and transported to another culture, the captured individuals have no say in how they will be treated or what behaviors they will be forced to practice. Often, as a matter of survival, they must learn some of the captors' language and behaviors; their original cultural dress may be removed and they may be given dress from the culture that captured them. This was often the practice with the capture of individuals to serve as slaves within the US culture. However, US slave records have suggested that, even with the provision of elements of dress from the enslaving culture, the enslaved found ways to modify dress to present and preserve their own cultural aesthetics, as in tying a headscarf to approximate a "wrapper" from their West African roots. What was a sign of oppression from plantation owners' perspectives may have _______________________ among female slaves, carrying forward into modern culture as various ornate wrapped headdresses.
* ornate: 화려하게 장식된
errors.correct: ② actually been a symbol of identity
errors.wrong: ⑤ been used to express a desire to enter the ruling culture

33. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

One advantage of thinking verbally is that language _______________________. By virtue of language and meaning, you can think about possible future events, about people who are far away, about promises made in the distant past. A rat or insect essentially lives in the immediate present and can respond only on the basis of what it can see, hear, and taste. Language allows people to see the present through the lens of those other, invisible facts and even to imagine possible events that have never occurred. This facility is powerfully helpful and liberating. As just one example, animals that have no language cannot possibly understand that some of this year's harvest has to be saved for planting next year, and they might eat their seed corn when they get hungry. They would feel better in the short run, but next year they would have nothing to plant and hence no crop at all. It is hardly an accident that our species is the only one to engage in farming, even though a great many species eat plants.
errors.correct: ① liberates you from the here and now
errors.wrong: ② enables you to separate fact from imagination

37. 주어진 글 다음에 이어질 글의 순서로 가장 적절한 것은?

Suppose you were asked to judge whether San Diego or San Antonio had a larger population. How would you go about making this judgment?

(A) However, what if you lived in another country and knew little about either city? In such a case, knowing less about each city might actually improve the judgment if the degree of recognition was all that was available to differentiate the options. In fact, nearly all Germans correctly judged that San Diego is the larger city.

(B) Conversely, Americans show greater expertise than Germans about the relative size of cities in Germany. When the degree that a stimulus seems familiar correlates with the criterion being judged (bigger, more famous, wealthier), having less information can actually increase the accuracy of judgment.

(C) You might use everything you know about each city (its location, history, number of prominent citizens) to make such an estimate, or you might simply decide whether you had better recognition of one city compared with the other (e.g., you have heard more about it or seen it mentioned more frequently). In either case, you might accurately judge that San Diego is, in fact, a larger city than San Antonio.

38. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은? [3점]

When we first come to attempt some task, we have accumulated almost none of the habit.

Learning is usually thought of as the relatively permanent acquired capability for performing some action. As such, experimenters often think of learning as a kind of "accumulated quantity." ( ① ) Many years ago, the state underlying performance was termed "habit," where we would say that practice "strengthens habit," and "stronger habit" allows more effective performance to occur. ( ② ) Of course, this says nothing about what habit is, but it does underscore the idea that we are attempting to study those principles that govern the accumulation of habit with practice. ( ③ ) Then, with additional practice, habit is thought to build in strength, and it is this stronger (in some sense) habit that allows improved performance to occur. ( ④ ) A key point is that our focus is not on the change in performance, but rather on the change in the state of habit that underlies performance. ( ⑤ ) This distinction is a critical one, and it is the basis for much of the methodology in the laboratory study of learning.
* underscore: 강조하다

39. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은?

Furthermore, your body will react by trying to remove further sensory insults.

The instinctive aversion we feel to harmful smells is combined with other physiological responses. For example, the trigeminal nerve can be triggered by irritant particles. ( ① ) This nerve stretches across your face and can send strong signals of pain when triggered. ( ② ) So not only will your brain tell you that you are at risk of being injured by whatever is giving off that horrible smell, it may also try to warn you from approaching it by making you experience physical pain. ( ③ ) Like the pain telling you to remove your hand from a burning metal surface, this pain aims to force you to move somewhere safer. ( ④ ) For instance, being exposed to a pungent smell might cause your eyes to tear and your nose to run, which may make it harder for you to breathe. ( ⑤ ) The increase in fluid production in your eyes and nose is to dilute whatever toxic molecules you were unlucky enough to breathe in, while the shortness of breath may be caused by your windpipes contracting in order to stop you from breathing in further particles.
* aversion: 혐오감  ** trigeminal nerve: 삼차 신경  *** pungent: 강하게 자극하는

40. 다음 글의 내용을 한 문장으로 요약하고자 한다. 빈칸 (A), (B)에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

In many contexts, people are motivated to make accurate judgments of others, unbiased by stereotypes and other factors. This motivation may arise from a temporary goal (e.g., to hire the best person for a position) or to consistently avoid prejudiced responses (e.g., to be an egalitarian person). These differing motivations to be accurate both contribute to reducing the application of activated stereotypes. In a study showing the former, participants who were told that they would have to share and explain their judgments of members of occupational groups showed lower use of stereotypes compared with participants whose judgments remained anonymous. Interestingly, participants who had to explain their ratings but in whom a cognitive load had been imposed showed higher levels of stereotyping. This result indicates that avoiding the use of stereotypes in judgment can be effortful, requiring cognitive resources. An example of the latter motivation is a study on the suppression of stereotypes. When people are instructed to avoid using stereotypes to judge others, they can succeed in doing so. When they are under a cognitive load or no longer feel that they need to inhibit their stereotypes, however, judgments are colored by stereotypical associations.
* egalitarian: 평등주의의  ** anonymous: 익명인

People who are motivated to judge others ___(A)___ can reduce reliance on stereotypes, but they are more likely to fall back on habitual biases when ___(B)___ cognitive strain.

From infancy, humans develop the ability to differentiate living things from inanimate objects based on movement patterns and sounds — animals move and sound differently than machines. Yet the neural systems responsible for these distinctions are imperfect, making it challenging to separate natural phenomena from what might seem supernatural. Our minds constantly scan for intentional actors, leading us to err when we hear mysterious sounds in darkness. What causes metal particles to move toward magnets? Why do swollen rivers appear furious? Dreams and visions reinforce our tendency to imagine various purposeful entities exist. Language reinforces this, as grammar requires actors for actions — we say wind \"blows\" and sun \"shines.\" _______________ because such mistakes typically carry fewer consequences than the reverse error. [B] [Even if / Even though] this tax has some supporters, it's not likely to pass because the average person doesn't want to be told how to eat by what some call the "fat police." 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것을 2개 고른 것은? (15점)

The famous primatologist Frans de Waal, of Emory University, says humans ⓐd̲o̲w̲n̲p̲l̲a̲y̲ ̲s̲i̲m̲i̲l̲a̲r̲i̲t̲i̲e̲s̲ ̲b̲e̲t̲w̲e̲e̲n̲ ̲u̲s̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲o̲t̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲n̲i̲m̲a̲l̲s̲ as a way of maintaining our spot at the top of our imaginary ladder. Scientists, de Waal points out, can be some of the worst offenders ─ employing technical language ⓑt̲o̲ ̲d̲i̲s̲t̲a̲n̲c̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲o̲t̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲n̲i̲m̲a̲l̲s̲ ̲f̲r̲o̲m̲ ̲u̲s̲. 20. 다음 글에서 필자가 주장하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

It is not the case that one can follow the law and assume that one is acting ethically. Throughout history, many laws have turned out to be an ethical disgrace when viewed with hindsight. Slavery is just one example of a situation that was legal, but that subsequently was declared immoral. Child labour is another. There are also laws and regulations that one has to break in certain situations if one is to act ethically. Jumping a red light or crossing a solid double line on the road may be the correct decision if it means getting a critically ill child to hospital sooner, and thereby increasing the chances of saving the child's life. Law and ethics are related, but they are not necessarily correlated or causally related. We must be cautious both when technology is changing and about allowing the law to take precedence over ethics. Particularly in the case of new technology, for example, technological singularity, a legal basis does not yet exist. In such cases, one must resort to the legal philosophy of the exception and the limitations of the law on the one hand, and ethical reflections on the other hand.
* disgrace: 수치  ** hindsight: 뒤늦은 깨달음  *** singularity: 특이점

The individual preoccupation with status or relative social position is not, from the perspective of evolutionary psychology, a character defect. It is, rather, an evolved adaptive mechanism to the ancestral reality that 'falling behind one's local rivals can be lethal'. When food supplies are intermittent because of wars or acts of nature, class affiliation is frequently the difference between survival and starvation. The law of natural selection is to blame for why people do not suffer the loss of status well, and will sometimes (if not frequently) resort to extreme measures to avoid it. The key point is that effective behavioral expressions of instinctive drives are culture- or context-specific. The immediate source of status could be hunting skill, age, number of wives or children, college admission scores, the make of a pickup truck, or the label on a woman's handbag. The purchase, use, and display of goods is the predominant means by which people seek to communicate their position to others in mature capitalist systems. Consumption behavior is also a primary object of imitation.
* lethal: 치명적인  ** intermittent: 간헐적인  *** affiliation: 소속

23. 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

One behavioral measurement of customer loyalty is the length of time a customer has been buying a brand. A shopper who has been purchasing a brand regularly for ten years would be considered more loyal than one who has been doing so for four years. However, relying on behavioral data alone is inadequate because it might only measure spurious loyalty, behavior that resembles brand loyalty but is not genuine loyalty caused by both true brand preference and regular buying. Rather, it is merely repeat purchase behavior (behavioral brand loyalty), buying a brand repeatedly due to factors such as indifference, convenience, low price, or unavailability of the preferred brand (versus brand preference). Consequently, in addition to behavioral data, marketers should also collect attitudinal or preference data such as measures of customer satisfaction, intent to repurchase, and brand advocacy, a measure of attitudinal loyalty that entails planning to recommend or recommending the brand to others. Brand advocacy can be measured simply by asking customers how likely they are to recommend a specific brand to a friend. Such customers can be leveraged to drive word-of-mouth campaigns.
* spurious: 겉보기만 그럴듯한  ** leverage: 활용하다
errors.correct: ① considerations for measuring true customer brand loyalty
errors.wrong: ③ behavioral characteristics of customers with strong brand loyalty

errors.question:
24. 다음 글의 제목으로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

Much of what we see and feel is selected by complex filtration systems, resulting in our perception of the wondrous world around us, at the cost of several illusions and limitations. Some of these costs are gladly paid for, whereas others are not. We begin with the very experience of time and space. The first illusion is our temporal orientation to the present. Although it may feel as if we are living in the now, the fact is that our perception lags behind real time by approximately 350 milliseconds, during which time information from the outside world is sensed, perceived, and interpreted by neural structures before being registered in conscious awareness. If we include our subsequent behavior, the estimation rises to 550 milliseconds−1 second. This means our conscious selves are actually perpetually living in the past. To compound this illusion, space is expanding and the Earth is moving rapidly, yet we do not feel as if the space we inhabit has changed, nor do we feel as if we are moving. We become accustomed to the constants in our lives, and it becomes easy to simply trust how we feel.
* perpetually: 영구히, 영속적으로
errors.correct: ⑤ The Illusion of Now: How Perception Distorts Time and Space
errors.wrong: ① What We Miss Keeps Us from Moving Forward

31. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

One of the central tenets of modern psychology is that perceptual and cognitive processes arise in the brain. Even if these processes are about objects in the world and perceived through sensory organs, the brain's role is still considered central. Implicit in this view is that all human brains are organized in similar ways. This turns out to be supported over and over again. For example, regardless of gender, age, ethnic background, racial identification, native language, and any other feature that distinguishes one human from another, brain regions serve the same functions across these distinctions. For example, the occipital lobe processes visual information for all sighted persons (indeed, all sighted mammals). Wernicke's area and Broca's area are language areas in all human brains. The primary auditory cortex processes input from the cochlea in all human brains. Neurosurgeons may need to be aware of slight deviations in individual human brains — one region may be shifted a few millimeters forward or backward relative to other individuals — but by and large, this rule of brain _____________ has been upheld in modern science.
* tenet: 신조, 주의  ** occipital lobe: 후두엽  *** cochlea: (귓속) 달팽이관

33. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

One advantage of thinking verbally is that language _______________________. By virtue of language and meaning, you can think about possible future events, about people who are far away, about promises made in the distant past. A rat or insect essentially lives in the immediate present and can respond only on the basis of what it can see, hear, and taste. Language allows people to see the present through the lens of those other, invisible facts and even to imagine possible events that have never occurred. This facility is powerfully helpful and liberating. As just one example, animals that have no language cannot possibly understand that some of this year's harvest has to be saved for planting next year, and they might eat their seed corn when they get hungry. They would feel better in the short run, but next year they would have nothing to plant and hence no crop at all. It is hardly an accident that our species is the only one to engage in farming, even though a great many species eat plants.
errors.correct: ① liberates you from the here and now
errors.wrong: ③ lets you enjoy the present moment more deeply

34. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

In his study of cooperative foraging among the Inujjuamiut, Eric Alden Smith found that the composition of foraging groups often conformed to predictions. For hunt types in which the highest per capita returns were achieved via solitary hunting, such as ptarmigan hunting, cooperative groups were rare. For other hunt types, however, there was frequently a mismatch between the observed group sizes and the seemingly optimal group size. When hunting beluga whales, for instance, per capita returns declined when group sizes exceeded 6 hunters, but the average group size was 10.7 individuals. In an analogous study of foraging in the Indonesian community of Lamalera, Michael Alvard and David A. Nolin determined that cooperative whaling provides higher per capita returns than other foraging activities. When whaling crews do not detect whales and resort to pursuits of other species, the per capita returns decline substantially as a function of crew size. Together, these two studies support the prediction that _______________________.
* foraging: 수렵 채집  ** solitary: 단독의  *** ptarmigan: 들꿩
errors.correct: ② observed group sizes will often exceed the optimum
errors.wrong: ③ solitary hunting will underperform cooperative hunting

Some concede that what gives meaning to life can occasionally change, yet believe that at each point in time there must be only one thing that gives life meaning.

(A) Nor do we think that there is anything inappropriate in performing various types of volunteer work (addressing various moral concerns, or benefiting different people), or in finding pleasure and happiness in different activities or hobbies.

(B) Thus, I may have a meaningful life thanks to my family life, my career, my hobby, my philanthropic activity, and my spiritual work at the same period of time. Of course, we would not want to spread ourselves too thin over too many aspects of life, but that is not the same thing as saying that we should focus only on one.

(C) But we do not regularly think that it is problematic to value various issues at the same time. For example, we do not think that there is anything wrong in taking aesthetic pleasure in many different paintings, in a variety of artistic styles, or in several different artistic fields (for example, both visual art and music).
* concede: 인정하다  ** philanthropic: 자선의  *** aesthetic: 미적인

39. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은?

Furthermore, your body will react by trying to remove further sensory insults.

The instinctive aversion we feel to harmful smells is combined with other physiological responses. For example, the trigeminal nerve can be triggered by irritant particles. ( ① ) This nerve stretches across your face and can send strong signals of pain when triggered. ( ② ) So not only will your brain tell you that you are at risk of being injured by whatever is giving off that horrible smell, it may also try to warn you from approaching it by making you experience physical pain. ( ③ ) Like the pain telling you to remove your hand from a burning metal surface, this pain aims to force you to move somewhere safer. ( ④ ) For instance, being exposed to a pungent smell might cause your eyes to tear and your nose to run, which may make it harder for you to breathe. ( ⑤ ) The increase in fluid production in your eyes and nose is to dilute whatever toxic molecules you were unlucky enough to breathe in, while the shortness of breath may be caused by your windpipes contracting in order to stop you from breathing in further particles.
* aversion: 혐오감  ** trigeminal nerve: 삼차 신경  *** pungent: 강하게 자극하는

41. 윗글의 제목으로 가장 적절한 것은?

In music direction, perfection of musical execution is the norm. It is also the expectation, conscious or not, of colleagues and audiences alike. Imperfection results in (a) visibility; people generally do not notice the workings of the music until they go wrong. Writers and directors (b) support absolute musical proficiency because fluency ensures maximum believability and comprehension. The better a language is spoken, the more communicative and emotional power it has. If stage music is supposed to appear from nowhere, it certainly should not trip and fall on its way in. For example, any audible flub by the accompanist at a vocal recital (who is by my definition the music director of the recital) is sure to turn the listener's attention to the piano when it should be on the (c) singer, and the pianist's error might well throw the singer off. Take another example: if an excessively loud music cue is suddenly heard in the midst of a quiet, tender dramatic moment of a play (or film), the intent of the drama will be (d) preserved. When music does encroach on a dramatic or entertainment setting on a stage, it should sound as if it belonged there, it should sound musically right, and it should leave a good impression. It is the music director's obligation to properly assimilate the music, to oversee its quality control, and to (e) connect the material with its listeners.
* flub: 실수  ** encroach: 끼어들다
errors.correct: ③ Blending in Perfectly: Music Must Belong, Not Distract
errors.wrong: ⑤ Perfect Music Performance: Key Features and Techniques

In an analogous study of foraging in the Indonesian community of Lamalera, Michael Alvard and David A. Nolin determined that cooperative whaling provides higher per capita returns than other foraging activities. 30. 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은? [3점]

Perception is not a passive process. The available amount of stimuli can be summarized and reduced through organization. This process is known as the "formation of super-signs." The first step entails the automatic "summarization" of similar signs or organizational structures into a super-sign, in which the ①essential elements are emphasized. This means that at first glance the observer does not perceive all details. He sees, for example, only the form of a wall with the most important openings but without any details. This ②increases the quantity of information available for reception. The work of information storage is diminished and we can thus ③better perceive and monitor our environment. 20. 다음 글에서 필자가 주장하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

It is not the case that one can follow the law and assume that one is acting ethically. Throughout history, many laws have turned out to be an ethical disgrace when viewed with hindsight. Slavery is just one example of a situation that was legal, but that subsequently was declared immoral. Child labour is another. There are also laws and regulations that one has to break in certain situations if one is to act ethically. Jumping a red light or crossing a solid double line on the road may be the correct decision if it means getting a critically ill child to hospital sooner, and thereby increasing the chances of saving the child's life. Law and ethics are related, but they are not necessarily correlated or causally related. We must be cautious both when technology is changing and about allowing the law to take precedence over ethics. Particularly in the case of new technology, for example, technological singularity, a legal basis does not yet exist. In such cases, one must resort to the legal philosophy of the exception and the limitations of the law on the one hand, and ethical reflections on the other hand.
* disgrace: 수치  ** hindsight: 뒤늦은 깨달음  *** singularity: 특이점
errors.correct: ⑤ 법이 항상 윤리를 보장하지 않기에 윤리적 판단이 우선되어야 한다.

22. 다음 글의 요지로 가장 적절한 것은?

The individual preoccupation with status or relative social position is not, from the perspective of evolutionary psychology, a character defect. It is, rather, an evolved adaptive mechanism to the ancestral reality that 'falling behind one's local rivals can be lethal'. When food supplies are intermittent because of wars or acts of nature, class affiliation is frequently the difference between survival and starvation. The law of natural selection is to blame for why people do not suffer the loss of status well, and will sometimes (if not frequently) resort to extreme measures to avoid it. The key point is that effective behavioral expressions of instinctive drives are culture- or context-specific. The immediate source of status could be hunting skill, age, number of wives or children, college admission scores, the make of a pickup truck, or the label on a woman's handbag. The purchase, use, and display of goods is the predominant means by which people seek to communicate their position to others in mature capitalist systems. Consumption behavior is also a primary object of imitation.
* lethal: 치명적인  ** intermittent: 간헐적인  *** affiliation: 소속
errors.correct: ⑤ 인간의 진화적 특성인 지위 유지 본능은 문화나 상황에 따라 다르게 표현된다.

23. 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

One behavioral measurement of customer loyalty is the length of time a customer has been buying a brand. A shopper who has been purchasing a brand regularly for ten years would be considered more loyal than one who has been doing so for four years. However, relying on behavioral data alone is inadequate because it might only measure spurious loyalty, behavior that resembles brand loyalty but is not genuine loyalty caused by both true brand preference and regular buying. Rather, it is merely repeat purchase behavior (behavioral brand loyalty), buying a brand repeatedly due to factors such as indifference, convenience, low price, or unavailability of the preferred brand (versus brand preference). Consequently, in addition to behavioral data, marketers should also collect attitudinal or preference data such as measures of customer satisfaction, intent to repurchase, and brand advocacy, a measure of attitudinal loyalty that entails planning to recommend or recommending the brand to others. Brand advocacy can be measured simply by asking customers how likely they are to recommend a specific brand to a friend. Such customers can be leveraged to drive word-of-mouth campaigns.
* spurious: 겉보기만 그럴듯한  ** leverage: 활용하다
errors.correct: ① considerations for measuring true customer brand loyalty
errors.wrong: ③ behavioral characteristics of customers with strong brand loyalty

31. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

One of the central tenets of modern psychology is that perceptual and cognitive processes arise in the brain. Even if these processes are about objects in the world and perceived through sensory organs, the brain's role is still considered central. Implicit in this view is that all human brains are organized in similar ways. This turns out to be supported over and over again. For example, regardless of gender, age, ethnic background, racial identification, native language, and any other feature that distinguishes one human from another, brain regions serve the same functions across these distinctions. For example, the occipital lobe processes visual information for all sighted persons (indeed, all sighted mammals). Wernicke's area and Broca's area are language areas in all human brains. The primary auditory cortex processes input from the cochlea in all human brains. Neurosurgeons may need to be aware of slight deviations in individual human brains — one region may be shifted a few millimeters forward or backward relative to other individuals — but by and large, this rule of brain _____________ has been upheld in modern science.
* tenet: 신조, 주의  ** occipital lobe: 후두엽  *** cochlea: (귓속) 달팽이관

32. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

The level of sharing is not always equal when cultures interact, but there is typically some degree of sharing. For example, when one group is captured and transported to another culture, the captured individuals have no say in how they will be treated or what behaviors they will be forced to practice. Often, as a matter of survival, they must learn some of the captors' language and behaviors; their original cultural dress may be removed and they may be given dress from the culture that captured them. This was often the practice with the capture of individuals to serve as slaves within the US culture. However, US slave records have suggested that, even with the provision of elements of dress from the enslaving culture, the enslaved found ways to modify dress to present and preserve their own cultural aesthetics, as in tying a headscarf to approximate a "wrapper" from their West African roots. What was a sign of oppression from plantation owners' perspectives may have _______________________ among female slaves, carrying forward into modern culture as various ornate wrapped headdresses.
* ornate: 화려하게 장식된
errors.correct: ② actually been a symbol of identity
errors.wrong: ⑤ been used to express a desire to enter the ruling culture

34. 다음 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은? [3점]

In his study of cooperative foraging among the Inujjuamiut, Eric Alden Smith found that the composition of foraging groups often conformed to predictions. For hunt types in which the highest per capita returns were achieved via solitary hunting, such as ptarmigan hunting, cooperative groups were rare. For other hunt types, however, there was frequently a mismatch between the observed group sizes and the seemingly optimal group size. When hunting beluga whales, for instance, per capita returns declined when group sizes exceeded 6 hunters, but the average group size was 10.7 individuals. In an analogous study of foraging in the Indonesian community of Lamalera, Michael Alvard and David A. Nolin determined that cooperative whaling provides higher per capita returns than other foraging activities. When whaling crews do not detect whales and resort to pursuits of other species, the per capita returns decline substantially as a function of crew size. Together, these two studies support the prediction that _______________________.
* foraging: 수렵 채집  ** solitary: 단독의  *** ptarmigan: 들꿩
errors.correct: ② observed group sizes will often exceed the optimum
errors.wrong: ③ solitary hunting will underperform cooperative hunting

38. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은? [3점]

When we first come to attempt some task, we have accumulated almost none of the habit.

Learning is usually thought of as the relatively permanent acquired capability for performing some action. As such, experimenters often think of learning as a kind of "accumulated quantity." ( ① ) Many years ago, the state underlying performance was termed "habit," where we would say that practice "strengthens habit," and "stronger habit" allows more effective performance to occur. ( ② ) Of course, this says nothing about what habit is, but it does underscore the idea that we are attempting to study those principles that govern the accumulation of habit with practice. ( ③ ) Then, with additional practice, habit is thought to build in strength, and it is this stronger (in some sense) habit that allows improved performance to occur. ( ④ ) A key point is that our focus is not on the change in performance, but rather on the change in the state of habit that underlies performance. ( ⑤ ) This distinction is a critical one, and it is the basis for much of the methodology in the laboratory study of learning.
* underscore: 강조하다

39. 글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은?

Furthermore, your body will react by trying to remove further sensory insults.

The instinctive aversion we feel to harmful smells is combined with other physiological responses. For example, the trigeminal nerve can be triggered by irritant particles. ( ① ) This nerve stretches across your face and can send strong signals of pain when triggered. ( ② ) So not only will your brain tell you that you are at risk of being injured by whatever is giving off that horrible smell, it may also try to warn you from approaching it by making you experience physical pain. ( ③ ) Like the pain telling you to remove your hand from a burning metal surface, this pain aims to force you to move somewhere safer. ( ④ ) For instance, being exposed to a pungent smell might cause your eyes to tear and your nose to run, which may make it harder for you to breathe. ( ⑤ ) The increase in fluid production in your eyes and nose is to dilute whatever toxic molecules you were unlucky enough to breathe in, while the shortness of breath may be caused by your windpipes contracting in order to stop you from breathing in further particles.
* aversion: 혐오감  ** trigeminal nerve: 삼차 신경  *** pungent: 강하게 자극하는

40. 다음 글의 내용을 한 문장으로 요약하고자 한다. 빈칸 (A), (B)에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

In many contexts, people are motivated to make accurate judgments of others, unbiased by stereotypes and other factors. This motivation may arise from a temporary goal (e.g., to hire the best person for a position) or to consistently avoid prejudiced responses (e.g., to be an egalitarian person). These differing motivations to be accurate both contribute to reducing the application of activated stereotypes. In a study showing the former, participants who were told that they would have to share and explain their judgments of members of occupational groups showed lower use of stereotypes compared with participants whose judgments remained anonymous. Interestingly, participants who had to explain their ratings but in whom a cognitive load had been imposed showed higher levels of stereotyping. This result indicates that avoiding the use of stereotypes in judgment can be effortful, requiring cognitive resources. An example of the latter motivation is a study on the suppression of stereotypes. When people are instructed to avoid using stereotypes to judge others, they can succeed in doing so. When they are under a cognitive load or no longer feel that they need to inhibit their stereotypes, however, judgments are colored by stereotypical associations.
* egalitarian: 평등주의의  ** anonymous: 익명인

People who are motivated to judge others ___(A)___ can reduce reliance on stereotypes, but they are more likely to fall back on habitual biases when ___(B)___ cognitive strain.
2. desertification

A psychologist at Yale University proposed a "fat tax." This tax would be for high-fat products, mainly junk food, like potato chips and hot dogs. It would be a "luxury tax," like the tax on tobacco and alcohol, [A] [that / which] are also products people use for personal pleasure even though they have high health risks. [B] [Even if / Even though] this tax has some supporters, it's not likely to pass because the average person doesn't want to be told how to eat by what some call the "fat police." Even if such a tax were to pass, I doubt it would help to reduce the number of overweight people. Obesity may be a social problem, but losing weight and practicing healthy eating habits is definitely a personal struggle [C] [that / what], of course, is not limited to only one.

errors.wrong: ③ A: which, B: Even though, C: that
